post_text: September is National Suicide Prevention Month. Suicidal thoughts can affect people of all ages, genders, ethnicities, and other backgrounds. According to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, 48,344 people died by suicide in 2018. It is important to have honest discussions about this serious topic so people become aware of the signs and are comfortable speaking about it. Throughout the month of September, we will be sharing posts related to suicide with hopes that it will foster conversation and awareness. If you have any concerns about your child’s mental health, please reach out to our school psychologists. If you suspect your child has suicidal thoughts, please IMMEDIATELY call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.

Eleven members of the Marlboro FCCLA, along with their two advisors, attended the National Family Career and Community Leaders of America Virtual Conference July 7-9. During the conference, the students had the opportunity to learn important life skills, compete in community service-based events, and chat virtually with other FCCLA members from across the country.

Seven Marlboro students served as evaluators and volunteers at the National level, while four others participated in STAR competitions under the guidance of Mrs. Giacoia and Mrs. Zehnacker. Aside from competing, the students immersed themselves in a wide variety of skill-based workshops, Red Talks (similar to TED Talks), and leadership training workshops. The also listened to several keynote speakers and watched various culinary and fashion design demonstrations from colleges across the country.

The Marlboro students and their advisors had a great time attending the virtual conference and are looking forward to bringing an innovative perspective to their chapters this fall!

post_text: Members of the Marlboro High School Class of 2020 took a memorable drive through their hometown on June 16, as part of a special motorcade that took place in their honor. The seniors lined up in their cars at Marlboro Elementary School, where they were surprised to see many of their earliest teachers. Then, upon exiting the parking lot and turning left onto Route 9W, the students were greeted by several of their former Marlboro Middle School teachers, who had lined the street to wave goodbye. Finally, after a quick drive through the Marlboro business district, it was on to the High School, where the soon-to-be graduates were greeted by faculty and staff members who had shown up to cheer, wave, and shout their goodbyes and/or well-wishes.

The Athletic Department will do their best to clear all registrants for the starting dates of August 24 (for Varsity and Junior Varsity sports) and September 2 (for Modified sports).

Parents/guardians should visit Marlboro’s FamilyID website, www.familyid.com/organizations/marlboro-central-school-district, to complete the online registration form. Once the student-athlete has been cleared by the Athletic Department and the School Medical Director, their name will be listed on the clear-to-play list and their coach will be notified. Please make sure that the School Nurse has a copy of your child's most up-to-date physical.

For more information, call Marlboro Athletic Director Jonnah O’Donnell at (845) 236-5806, or email jonnah.odonnell@marlboroschools.org.

New York State's 37 BOCES have launched an online conversation regarding how New Yorkers feel about returning to school in the fall or whenever it is possible. It consists of a single question: "What ideas and thoughts do you have as you think about a return to in-person schooling?"

A virtual conversation tool called Thoughtexchange is being used to crowdsource ideas. To participate in the exchange, visit: https://my.thoughtexchange.com/333518046.

After participants share a thought, they are encouraged to rate at least 30 of the thoughts submitted by other participants. This way, the thoughts that resonate with the most participants rise to the top.

“Understanding the thoughts and concerns of our stakeholders regarding reopening our school buildings is critical,” said Dr. Charles V. Khoury, district superintendent of Ulster BOCES. "The decisions before us are unprecedented, and we want to ensure our parents and community have a voice in this important conversation."

Under New York State law, a school district must plan its budget around a complex formula that calculates the allowable tax levy increase for each district. With a tax levy increase of 1.91 percent, Marlboro’s budget proposal meets the criteria for a simple majority voter approval of 50 percent plus one.

This year’s budget vote and school board election will be conducted by absentee ballot only. Qualified voters of the school district will receive absentee ballots by mail. Completed ballots must be received by the District Clerk by 5 PM on June 9 in order to be counted.

For more information about Marlboro's proposed budget, visit www.marlboroschools.org.

Last week, Grade 5 teacher Mrs. Bogaczyk came up with a school-wide challenge, asking Marlboro Elementary School students to print or decorate a piece of paper with the phrase “We Are MES.” Many students and staff participated, submitting photos of themselves smiling while holding their colorful creations. Not only is the challenge helping to spread strength and love during this challenging time, but it is also proving to the Marlboro community and beyond that we are stronger together.

Be well, stay positive, and keep your photos coming! If you don’t see your photo included in the slideshow, we’d love for you to send it to us in a private message and we will post in the comments below. (Middle and High School students are welcome to participate too!)

Remember, we’re in this together and we will get through this together. #WeAreMES #MarlboroStrong 🧡🖤🧡

post_text: Marlboro Middle School (MMS) celebrated National No One Eats Alone Day on February 13 with a special event in the school cafeteria. Grade 6 students sat at different tables during their lunch period and participated in icebreaker activities with students they do not normally sit with. Grade 7 and 8 Junior Ambassadors facilitated the activities, along with Middle School counselors. Students were treated to cupcakes courtesy of the MMS PTA and entertainment by Paper Jam, the MMS faculty band. A fun time was had by all during this nationwide effort to end social isolation and create a culture of belonging for everyone!

"It has been a wonderful opportunity to encourage reading in a new and unique way!”

post_text: Last month, FCCLA members from Marlboro Middle and High School hosted a dinner honoring first responders in our community. Deni Menendez and Lizi Gordiashvili spearheaded the campaign, which began with Marlboro students submitting letters nominating their heroes. In total, eighteen firefighters, three police officers, and seven EMTs from Marlboro and the surrounding area were honored during the event. The FCCLA members acted as hosts during the evening, performing an original skit, serving a hero’s feast, and emceeing an award ceremony. This event was completely planned and executed by the students, with guidance from advisers Ann Marie Giacoia and Chelsea Wolfert. The FCCLA hopes to make this an annual event, honoring different groups each year. We appreciate the first responders who attended the event and are grateful for their service!

This fall, the Marlboro Faculty Association challenged Marlboro Elementary and Middle School students to an at-home Read-A-Thon. Led by Ms. Taddeo and Mrs. Keane, the P.O.P (Power of Pages) Read-A-Thon focused on the power that reading has on students’ lives and how reading can be used to influence others. Family members and friends made pledges to donate to the students’ reading goals and the pledges were later gifted to families in our community who are battling cancer and cancer-related illnesses.

At the end of the challenge, students not only met their goals but greatly surpassed them. Congratulations to our top readers, Marlboro Elementary School students Ben Kovacs, Lukas Magyar, and Tenecia Hart, and Marlboro Middle School student Emma Stoebling.

Ms. Taddeo and Mrs. Keane are proud of their students and grateful to all those who supported this effort. Students brought smiles to many faces this holiday season and made a huge difference in the lives of others by “turning the pages” to a cure!

post_text: A group of Marlboro Middle School students immersed themselves in the democratic process during the YMCA Model Legislature, held at the Capitol building in Albany last month. The students joined other student delegates from throughout New York State as they debated bills on the Assembly and Senate floors. This was a wonderful opportunity that gave students the chance to learn about a variety of complex issues, develop their critical thinking skills, and articulate their beliefs while engaging with their peers from around the State. The students represented Marlboro well and their preparation for the event paid off. All of their bills were passed on the Assembly floor and several students received special recognition. Deni Menendez was recognized as an outstanding delegate, Emily Schaffer was recognized as an outstanding debater, and a bill proposed by Deni Menendez, Sophia Dunn, Sophia Montalbano, and Audrey Lee was recognized as an outstanding bill. Way to go!

Mrs. Feeney decorated her classroom using colorful displays and props straight out of the popular Pixar movie franchise. Students rotated through centers where they wrote sentences by pulling words out of a claw machine from Pizza Planet, practiced their measuring skills to help fix Slinky Dog, and explored eSpark learning software in a blanket fort in Andy’s room. There was a photo booth, lots of art projects, and a STEAM challenge that required them to use ozobots to rescue Buzz. The students even used logic and reasoning to help solve the case of who stole Bo Peep's missing sheep (turns out it was Lotso!) All this and more made for a very exciting week of learning for these Grade 1 students!
